column1: I just booked a trip for April. Anyone concerned about the Coronavirus?

the only thing that concerns me personally at the moment is if the world is in such a panic that flights are cancelled thus preventing us from getting down there. In fact we might benefit if we get stuck ON Anguilla :)Observing more-careful than normal hygiene (hand washing, no touching face, etc) seems prudent. But everyone has their own level of risk tolerance.
Superb post RMG. You make a lot of sense.
"French couple taken off airport after being flagged as suspected corona virus cases".Daily Herald SXM article today:https://www.thedailyherald.sx/islands/french…

Poor sods, I feel for them. I travelled this week from Sydney to London on BA and because of slight cough as a former smoker, I was worried to be taken of the flight in Singapore...luckily the airline captain had more common sense.
Tilly, paranoia has set in; it is a terrible situation when people can be quarantined for no reason. How awful for them, and for us to have to live in fear.I hope Covid-19 has a speedy ending.

Bless their hearts. Everyone who coughs or has a cold is now suspected of being a carrier. I’m all for being cautious, but we need to “keep a cool head even if our pants burn off” as my father says. Hubby and I arrived at SXM yesterday bound for AXA around the time this may have been going on. Personally, I’d love for our government to issue a two week in place quarantine for any of us currently outside the US. I could really handle sheltering in place on Meads Bay!

We are traveling to the island in April as well. We are also traveling with someone with a compromised immune system. We are more worried about one of us contracting influenza and passing it along to said traveling companion. We will be wearing masks, but we were always going to be traveling wearing them. Now we just won't stand out as much, I guess !
It is largely a liberal media-induced panic. The risks of contracting the virus are minimal, although the risk of travel delays are real. Face masks will not protect you.
hahahahaah, thanks professor.

Actually the media is reporting what the scientists are saying. They're experts by virtue of experience and education. I suppose those who find anything involving educated experts to be inherently liberal will have good reason to distrust them. And this being a travel forum, what better place to interject such political viewpoints.

KAP nothing could be further from the truth, The facts are that over 90,000 people have the coronavirus and over 3000 have died. These numbers are from the WHO and have nothing to do with the media. Listen to the scientists not the politicians
Having said that, I would have no problem visiting AXA and being a little more cautious as mentioned previously. Here is a good site for COVID-19 informationhttps://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/

And 90% of those cases are in China.And, in any event, do not even approach the number of cases/deaths from influenza.But spreading fear of an epidemic is the only way to reign in the economy, which in turn is the only way to derail a second term for Trump.

The Ministry of Health reiterated that there are no cases on the island and that they are doing all they can to keep Anguilla Coronavirus free. I would go by press releases through the Ministry of Health, The Anguilla Tourist Board, and the Government of Anguilla. All other hotels were represented in this meeting as well as all levels of Government.

Just returned from AXA, all was fine. However, yesterday, SXM government announced that flights from US, as well as Europe, will not be allowed to land after Tuesday 3/17. Period is for two weeks. PHILIPSBURG–All international flights and cruises originating from the United States of America, Europe and the United Kingdom to Sint Maarten will be cancelled for two weeks as of Tuesday, March 17, Chairperson of the Emergency Operations Center (EOC) Prime Minister Silveria Jacobs said in a national address today, Saturday. As of March 14, up until and including Monday, March 16, there is an opportunity for St. Maarten students studying abroad and residents as well as essential personnel to return to the country ahead of the two-week travel restrictions. The travel restrictions do not apply for regional air and sea travel at this time. Travel within the Dutch Caribbean: Saba, St. Eustatius, Bonaire, Aruba, and Curacao remains in place until further notice. This travel restriction also applies to other seafaring vessels. Jacobs said arrangements will be put in place for visitors to return home with their carriers. Cargo flights/vessels bringing in food supplies, household goods, oil, gas, as well as medicine will continue. Also allowed, will be travel by technical and medical assistants whether via commercial or chartered airlines.“All residents and nationals traveling back to Sint Maarten from the United States, Europe and the United Kingdom during this period, are recommended to monitor their health for 14-days for consistent cough, fever or respiratory problems (consistent with COVID-19) and maintain a social distance for the safety and security of the community. If you experience the aforementioned symptoms, please call your family physician. Do not go to your doctor or the medical center. During the phone call with your doctor, you will be advised further what actions should be taken,” she stressed.  The PM said these preventive measures are to limit the exposure of the Sint Maarten people to COVID-19 due to an increase in COVID-19 cases in Europe and the United States of America and based on the World Health Organisation (WHO’s) declaration on Wednesday, March 11, that the coronavirus has become a global pandemic. “Based on this declaration, the Government of Sint Maarten has stepped up its preparations and today March 14, after deliberation with the Council of Ministers and the EOC a number of decisions have been taken,” she said.
